Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: I/UCRC for Center for Health Organization Transformation
Award.AbstractNarration:
This planned center site at the University of Alabama - Birmingham (UAB) for the I/UCRC for Health Organization Transformation (CHOT) intends to focus on the evaluation of health care delivery innovations, such as information technology, care coordination, and facility design strategies with the ultimate goal of generating knowledge that may result in efficient, high-quality care that is patient-centered and equitable. Our research activities align well with the proposed focus of the UAB CHOT site, and can be organized into seven domains: 1) information technology, 2) care coordination, 3) facility design, 4) efficiency, 5) quality of care, 6) patient-centeredness, and 7) equity. The new site plans to expand on CHOT's existing capacity, extend the geographic reach of the CHOT in the Southeast, and broaden the types of industry partners involved in CHOT.

With health care costs in the U.S. reaching nearly 18% of GDP in 2011, and projections of this rate increasing to 20% by 2020, the need to identify ways to "bend the cost curve" has never been more critical. It is important to develop meaningful and multi-disciplinary partnerships between academic institutions and industry partner to yield innovative solutions to various issues in the U.S. health care system. They can also facilitate practice-based research related to the development and assessment of various health care delivery interventions. UAB's affiliation with the CHOT I/UCRC will facilitate and accelerate such research in our region by joining an experienced learning collaborative, and by leveraging the resources of UAB and potential industry partners. UAB's participation in the CHOT will enhance our graduate student experience in the classroom and in the field, and will provide faculty with opportunities for practice-based, multi-disciplinary research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of the I/UCRC planning grant was to explore the feasibility of developing a University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB) site of the Center for Health Organization Transformation (CHOT). The UAB CHOT site will consist of an academic/industry learning collaborative (I/UCRC) to engage in practice-based research on health care delivery innovations. Our goal will be achieved by leveraging the resources of a major research university and our industry partners. Our collaborative will be multidisciplinary, multi-sectorial, and multi-state. UAB CHOT’s research team will include a multi-disciplinary collaboration from two departments across two UAB schools: Department of Health Services Administration (School of Health Professions) and the Department of Civil, Construction, and Environmental Engineering (School of Engineering). Our potential industry partners represent a broad spectrum of organizations that includes health care (hospital, home health, hospice, and rehabilitation), health promotion, quality improvement, telecommunications, and construction. 

We propose to focus on the evaluation of health care delivery innovations, such as information technology, care coordination, and facility design strategies. Our ultimate goal is to generate knowledge with respect to health care delivery innovations that may result in efficient, high-quality care that is patient-centered and equitable.

A planning meeting with potential industry partners was held at the UAB campus on September 15-16, 2014. We had representation from 16 industry partners and from NSF, CHOT, and UAB leadership and faculty members and students.  During this meeting we discussed the values, vision and capabilities of the proposed UAB CHOT site. In addition, UAB faculty presented seven project proposals. Potential industry members evaluated and provided feedback on the proposed projects via the LIFE forms. UAB faculty members had an opportunity to address feedback from industry participants. Finally, NSF had a closed session with industry participants to gauge interest of industry members in the UAB CHOT site. There was strong endorsement from industry participants. Next steps have consisted of marketing the UAB CHOT site and securing financial commitment from industry partners. We were able to secure a combination of financial and in-kind contributions from five industry partners. A UAB CHOT Center application was submitted on April 3, 2015.

Intellectual Merit

The U.S. health care system, with its incentives to provide more care, has produced highly fragmented care that emphasizes specialty and acute care over coordination, patient centeredness, and population health management. With health care costs in the U.S. reaching nearly 18% of GDP in 2011, and projections of this rate increasing to 20% by 2020, the need to identify ways to “bend the cost curve” has never been more critical. Furthermore, the consistent increase in health care expenditure is not mirrored by quality outcomes, with the U.S. lagging OECD countries in various quality metrics. Recent health care reform efforts in the U.S. have attempted to address some of these systemic issues. However, in order to achieve the desired health system improvements, it is imperative to embrace system-wide changes such as effective utilization of healthcare information technology and work process reengineering, including redesigning and repurposing facilities to improve access to care as well as to optimize patient flow and care coordination across variety of conditions, providers and sites, over time.
